Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Evolution of Winds in Dust Disks Around Stars
Award.AbstractNarration:
Planets formed from material in disks of gas and dust that once surrounded the stars they orbit. The way that these disks form and how material is spread throughout the disks affect both how quickly material is added to the stars themselves and what types of planets can form in the disks. Disk winds play a major role in the way this material is dispersed. In this study, the investigators build on their earlier work where they observed the disk winds in 33 disks. They observed two parts to the winds: a wind driven by magnetic/electric interactions and a wind driven by temperature differences. With this grant the investigators will extend their study to include a large number of much older disks with the goals of measuring how much the magnetic/electric process drives with wind and how much the thermal heating drives the wind. This project serves the national interest as it expands our understanding of the science behind the formation of planetary systems around other stars. A graduate student, a postdoc, and at least three undergraduate students will participate in this study. The investigators will also participate in a K-12 teacher workshop at The University of Arizona, reaching Hispanic and Native American communities. A two-week long astronomy class will be taught to high school girls from around the world in the annual Smith Summer Science and Engineering Program.

The analysis of optical [OI] emission lines for the 33 disks in Taurus reveals two low-velocity kinematic components, one of which (broad component) likely traces a magnetohydrodynamic (MHD)-driven wind while the other (narrow component) might be associated with a thermally-driven wind. The investigators will establish empirically how disk winds evolve by measuring the relative proportion of MHD-driven and thermally-driven winds. They will also measure wind mass loss rates through the main stages of disk evolution and dispersal. They will extend their analysis of the [OI] lines to a sample of more evolved disks, including more disks with dust cavities, and analyze one of the blue [SII] transitions to clarify the thermal contribution to the [OI] emission.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this collaborative project on the evolution of disk winds, we have found on the basis of a comprehensive analysis of forbidden line emission from young stars that this emission arises from winds driven from the inner few au regions of their protoplanetary disks. We have used line ratios and several emission line diagnostics to investigate the relative contributions of thermal and magnetically driven winds and infer the mass loss rates implied by the observed emission.
Intellectual Merit:
We have analyzed high resolution observations of forbidden line emission from  OI 6300A, OI 5577A  and SII 4068A for a sample of 48 stars and found that the profiles are similar. They can all be decompsosed into low and high velocity components (LVC and HVC) and from the excitation conditions inferred by the line ratios we conclude that they all arise from thermal excitation in dense gas in MHD winds. In the slow wind, we find that gas densities are high, ~1e7-1e8 cm-3 and gas temperatures are ~ 5e3-1e4 K. The HVC component emission is better explained by shocks in jets, and mass loss rates are found to be modest and about a tenth of the accretion rates, in agreement with previous estimates. We found that mass loss rates in the accompanying slow winds could be substantially higher and may play an important role in disk mass evolution.
We also conducted a systematic analysis of the kinematics of the wind from a large sample of 65 disks spanning a range of evolutionary stages. We found that the LVC and HVC are kinematically linked and show correlations between the centroid velocities and the line widths, and are both correlated with the accretion luminosity, supporting origin in an MHD wind. The optical lines were compared with [NeII] infrared emission and we find that the OI line emission becomes weaker as the inner disk dust emission decreases, but the NeII emission becomes stronger. Interestingly, we find that OI lines are detected in both the HVC and LVC but NeII emission is seen only one of the two components. We envisage an evolutionary trend where at early stages, the inner disk is dusty and has molecular winds launched which shield the outer disk regions. At later stages the inner disk is depleted, OI lines become weaker and NeII emission arises from a weaker wind in the outer disk.
Broader Impact:
The results from this work were presented by the PI at various events including review talks at the ACS in New Orleans (3/2018) and the LAD/AAS meeting in Denver (6/2018) and at various invited colloquia at universities. REU students Sean Haas and Noah Goldman were mentored as part of this project and a master's student (Jacob Elliott) was directly involved as an intern to work on cooling functions.
